parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>The provided data does not contain any information suggesting the presence of a CMF number in the Facebook post.  The absence of a CMF number doesn't automatically disqualify it as propaganda, as it could be from a non-candidate entity. However, it's a factor to consider.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>The image and text strongly suggest an appeal to the Hungarian-speaking population in Romania to vote in the parliamentary elections. While no specific candidate is named, the message urges voters to prevent "anti-Hungarian forces" from winning, implicitly endorsing candidates who represent Hungarian interests. This aligns with Article 36 (7) - a, as it directly relates to a group of candidates participating in the elections.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>The Facebook post, being a paid advertisement on a public platform, clearly targets a wide population, specifically the Hungarian-speaking community in Romania. This satisfies Article 36 (7) - c.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>The primary objective of the post is to encourage a specific segment of the population to vote for candidates aligned with their interests. The phrasing "December 1st, Hungarians cannot lose" is a direct call to action with a clear electoral objective. This fulfills Article 36 (7) - c.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>The post does not present itself as journalistic. It lacks objectivity and instead promotes a specific political viewpoint and encourages voting for a particular group of candidates. It does not adhere to journalistic standards of impartiality and balanced reporting.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>The content transcends personal opinion; it's a clear political message aimed at influencing electoral behavior. The urgency and direct call to action ("Don't let Hungarians lose") are not characteristic of a personal opinion.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>1133970618342201</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post, with its image and text, constitutes electoral propaganda.  It targets a specific demographic (Hungarian speakers in Romania) with a clear message urging them to vote to prevent a perceived threat to their interests. The post's timing, close to election day, and its direct call to action strongly suggest an intention to influence the outcome of the parliamentary elections. While no specific candidate is named, the implicit endorsement of candidates representing Hungarian interests makes it a form of electoral propaganda. The paid nature of the post on a public platform further strengthens this conclusion.  The absence of a CMF number is not sufficient to negate the evidence of electoral propaganda.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>TRUE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates>
  <candidate><name>UDMR candidates</name><impact>POSITIVE</impact></candidate>
</electoral-propaganda-candidates>
<responsible-party-or-group>RMDSZ</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police>
RMDSZ Bihar Megye, pentru încălcarea articolului 98 t) din LEGEA nr. 208 din 20 iulie 2015, prin publicarea pe Facebook, după ora 18:00 pe 23.11.2024, a unei postări (ID 1133970618342201) cu conținut electoral, care îndeamnă populația maghiară din România să voteze pentru a preveni o presupusă amenințare la adresa intereselor lor, având un efect electoral clar prin îndemnul direct la vot ("Pe 1 decembrie, maghiarii nu pot pierde").  Postarea, deși nu numește candidați specifici, susține implicit candidații care reprezintă interesele maghiare, constituind astfel propagandă electorală după încheierea perioadei legale de campanie.  Caracterul plătit al postării pe o platformă publică întărește această concluzie.
</message-for-police>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
